mainmatter.p: The spectrum of a noetherian ring is always noetherian: the closeds corresponds to radical ideals. The converse does not hold. Consider a polynomial ring with infinitely many indeterminates x_1, x_2, \dots quotiented by the relations x_k^k = 0. The ideals in the quotient ring correspond to ideals in the polynomial ring dividing x_k^k for every k. So there are only two radical ideals: the trivial one, and the one that divides all indeterminates, but not constants. Hence the spectrum must be a noetherian space, but the ring is obviously not noetherian since it is not finitely generated itself.

The ideals of R[S^{-1}] are generated by images of ideals in R under the localization map, written as \mathfrak { b } [S^{-1}], isomorphic to \mathfrak { b } \otimes _R R[S^{-1}].

A space is noetherian if every descending chain of closeds, or equivalently every ascending chain of opens stabilizes. In other words, the partial order of closeds is well-founded.

frontmatter.title: Topological spectrum of a commutative ring

mainmatter.p: The topological spectrum of a commutative ring R, denoted \operatorname {Spec} (R), is a topological space whose points are given by prime ideals of R. We denote the point corresponding to \mathfrak { p } as \left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ]. We define an open D( \mathfrak { a } ) for each ideal \mathfrak { a } which contains the point \left [ \mathfrak { p } \right ] when \mathfrak { p } \nmid \mathfrak { a }. The corresponding closed is written as V( \mathfrak { a } ).
We abuse the notation and write D(f) for the case where \mathfrak { a } is generated by f. Similar notations apply to V.
